p.s: In the following I will analyse Barnier's way of conveying his criticism by looking at his line of argumentation, his choice of words and use of stylistic devices.
The speakersspeaker's line of argumentation is very straight and one-sided, displaying his strict disagreement with Brexit.

In his speech he is constantly referingreferring to the create [of] friction to trade (l. 5) and his conviction that we are stronger together (l. 2) using we to refer to the UK and the EU, including everyone using empathy.
In addition his use of a very formal speech and the use of will (l. 5) show his seriousness in the issue, as well as his unwillingness to even slightly consider Brexit to be good.
This is also supported by him stating that Brexit is a clear [...] lose-lose situation for both (l. 9f.), using the anaphora and colloquialism to further empathise his point.
Barnier also empathises the chain of consequences by repeatedly using this (ll. 5, 6, 7), causing an alliteration.

In the following part of his speech he talks about ways to achieve a close relationship between the EU and the UK, often comparing the latter's situation to that of the USA, as they aren't a member of the union, but still have access to the EU Single Market (cf. ll. 16-18).
He concludes that part by asking the rethoricalrhetorical question of Why?, getting the audience to think about why the equivalence system that works for the US not work for the UK.

He concludes his speech by restating his position, as a member of the EU, that the EU will not change who we are (l. 27) because the UK is leaving, reestablishing his position, and that of the listener's, that we as the EU will try to incorporate the UK, but refuse to change because of them.

In conclusion, Michel Barnier states his discontent with the UK's decision to leave the EU, but will try his best to lessen the coming hardships for the both of them, while refusing to change the EU as a whole.
